;周三，印度尼西亚首都雅加达位居全球污染最严重城市榜首，根据瑞士空气质量技术公司 IQAir 的数据，自 5 月份以来，雅加达跻身全球污染最严重的 10 个城市之列。

;

;人口超过 1000 万的雅加达几乎每天都有不健康的空气污染水平，据 IQAir 称。

;

;它定期记录 PM2.5 微小颗粒浓度的“不健康”水平，PM2.5 可以穿透呼吸道导致呼吸系统问题，是世界卫生组织建议水平的许多倍。

;

;

;

; p>;

;居民里兹基·普特拉 (Rizky Putra) 感叹，不断恶化的空气质量让他孩子们的健康面临风险。

;

;“我认为情况非常令人担忧，”35 岁的里兹基 (Rizky) 在路边说道。 ”在雅加达市中心。

;

;他说：“许多儿童都患有相同的症状，例如咳嗽和感冒。”

;

;据估计，空气污染导致 700 万人过早死亡每年都有人死亡，被联合国认为是最大的环境健康风险。

;

;雅加达居民长期以来一直抱怨长期交通、工业烟雾和燃煤发电厂带来的有毒空气。其中一些人于 2021 年发起并赢得了民事诉讼，要求政府采取行动控制空气污染。

;

;当时的法院裁定佐科维总统必须制定国家空气质量标准以保护人类健康，并且卫生部长和雅加达省长必须制定控制空气污染的策略。

;

;出于安全考虑，印度尼西亚推迟中资铁路的开通

;

;不过，空气质量应用程序联合创始人 Nathan Roestandy Nafas Indonesia 表示，污染程度持续恶化。

;

;“我们每天呼吸超过 20,000 次。如果我们每天吸入被污染的空气，可能会导致呼吸道和肺部疾病，甚至哮喘。它会影响儿童的认知发展，甚至心理健康。”他说。

;

;周二被问及雅加达的污染问题时，维多多总统告诉记者，解决方案是将国家首都从雅加达迁往努桑塔拉，他的政府目前正在婆罗洲岛上从头开始建设。

;

;印度尼西亚将于明年将努桑塔拉命名为新首都，至少 16,000 名公务员、军队和警察将迁往那里。< /p>;

;维多多还表示，“必须完成”横跨雅加达的规划地铁网络，以减少污染。

;

;印度尼西亚已承诺从 2023 年起停止建设新的燃煤发电厂，并实现碳排放到 2050 年实现中立。

;

;尽管活动人士强烈抗议，政府仍在爪哇岛扩建苏拉亚煤电厂，该电厂是东南亚最大的煤电厂之一。

;

;据印度尼西亚绿色和平组织称，首都方圆 100 公里（62 英里）内有 10 座燃煤发电厂正在运营。

;北京向联合国提交了一份严厉的工作文件，反对东京释放经过处理的放射性水从福岛核电站排入太平洋的过程最快可能在8月底开始。

;

;“如果所谓的‘处理过的水’真的安全无害，日本为什么不处理掉呢？”在自己的领土内使用还是用于工农业目的？”周二提交的文件称。

;

;日本计划从核电站倾倒超过 100 万吨水，该核电站的三座反应堆在 2011 年地震和海啸后发生熔毁。

;

;虽然很大程度上受到东京保证此举安全的影响，但日本、日本和该地区其他地方的人们已经走上街头抗议这一有争议的安排。

;

;但北京和莫斯科迄今为止，唯一在州一级表达反对意见的政府。

;

;福岛超过 70% 的废水未达标：中国监管机构

;

;北京方面的问题呼应了自核安全以来一直在酝酿的批评。辩论的早期阶段。

;

;2021 年，瓦努阿图女政治家 Motarilavoa Hilda Lini 表示：“如果安全，请将其倾倒在东京，在巴黎进行测试，然后存放在华盛顿，但保留我们的太平洋核能-免费。”

;

;中国表示此举将“以牺牲自然环境和人类健康为代价”。但日本指责北京无视其坚称的该计划背后的合理科学依据，并对其自己的核电站发生了更严重的泄漏事件。

;

;“没有人为地将核污染水排放到海洋中的先例，没有国际公认的处置标准，”中国在文件中辩称，该文件出现在正在举行的 2026 年《不扩散核武器条约》（NPT）审议大会筹备委员会会议上。会谈将于周五结束。

;< p>;它敦促日本停止其排放计划，咨询邻国和其他利益相关者，接受“严格的国际监督”，并安全、透明和科学地处理核污染水。

;

;原口浩司，日本山梨学院大学政治学讲师表示，中国的工作文件是对日本政府最高发言人松野裕和7月份敦促中国“基于科学证据进行讨论”言论的“直接回应”。

;<尽管北京和莫斯科共同要求澄清有关该程序的三项技术问题，但原口表示，这些要求可能会使东京更不可能停止或推迟推迟，因为东京“不想因为来自日本的压力而放弃决定”。中国和俄罗斯”。

;

;联合国机构国际原子能机构 (IAEA) 于 7 月初发布了为期两年的审查报告，确定日本的计划符合其安全标准。中方在声明中表示，日方不应利用该报告作为排污的“挡箭牌”或“绿灯”。

;

;“国际原子能机构仅根据日方提供的数据和信息进行审查和评估。”报告称，报告中使用的数据和信息“未经证实”，其结论“缺乏足够的说服力”。 ”。

;

;为什么中国、韩国仍然反对福岛污水处理计划？

;

;苏格兰圣安德鲁斯大学国际关系博士后研究员张驰表示，鉴于对日本近邻海岸以外的排放影响的考虑相对适度，该工作文件的潜在影响“仍然有限”。

;

;“虽然《不扩散核武器条约》在遏制核武器和技术方面发挥着关键作用核扩散，它在决定一个国家有关核废水管理的行动方针方面的效力本质上是受到限制的，”张说。 “缺乏强有力的执法措施来迫使各国保持一致。”

;

;张说，“迫切需要”建立平台，使科学评估和外交谈判能够更深入地结合起来，并提供平衡公共安全、环境问题和区域考虑。

;

;“理想的情况是邻国动员自己的专家小组合作协助日本制定拟议排放计划的替代战略，或制定监测框架以确保辐射安全张说。

;

;中国表示，日本“没有对所有处置方案进行彻底研究”——其中还包括释放蒸汽和氢气、地面注入和地下掩埋——并坚持将海洋

;

;北京非政府智库中国与全球化智库高级研究员莫国强表示，虽然尚不确定该文件是否会影响日本态度的改变，暴露了该地区许多人的共同担忧。

;

;“中国提出的一个关键问题是日本不愿将处理过的水用于国内工业或农业目的，这可能会导致很可能成为联合国要求东京解决的问题之一，”莫说。 “难题出现了：在处理过的水的释放方面，谁拥有科学和外交上的最终权力？”

;

;他表示，该地区国家的立场受到公共卫生和环境以外的因素的影响.

;

;“地方政府的沉默反应令人困惑，但一些国家公开反对这一决定，了解他们的动机至关重要，”莫说。

;

;“美国和澳大利亚对日本计划的支持可能被视为两国联盟和当前地缘政治格局的体现——这种支持可能会进一步加剧中国与西方本已紧张的关系。”

;

;原口表示，各国政府对政治立场持不同立场原因。

;

;“鉴于美国公民在国内的环境担忧要低得多，[他们接受]国际原子能机构的证书，以及华盛顿作为日本盟友的地位，美国可以支持日本的计划，”原口说。< /p>;

;“由于地理位置靠近日本，中国和俄罗斯都对公共卫生问题存在高度或足够的担忧，而对反对东京决定的外交和安全担忧则较低或有限。”

;

;原口说韩国公众在这个问题上“存在严重分歧”，韩国总统尹锡烈尽管反映出首尔需要“与日本重建更紧密的安全和经济关系以应对朝鲜的挑战”，但仍与东京达成协议。

;

;民意调查显示十分之八的韩国人反对日本的放水计划。

;

;张指出，首尔的立场与其继续禁止来自福岛地区的食品和海鲜产品不一致，但韩国的立场西方国家对此是意料之中的。

;

;“从历史上看，向太平洋处置核废料一直是美国和欧洲等实体的做法，”张说。 “七国集团内部没有反对也凸显了地缘政治因素比环境问题更重要。”

;香港首席伊玛目在据称，13 岁男孩在宗教学习中心遭到殴打，导致眼睛受伤，需要进行六个小时的手术。

;

;与受害者父亲交谈的穆夫提·穆罕默德·阿尔沙德 (Mufti Muhammad Arshad) 周四告诉《华盛顿邮报》据称，这起袭击事件发生在周六早上，地点是一个向学生教授《古兰经》的学习中心。

;

;伊玛目证实，该中心的大多数学生都是巴基斯坦裔，包括受害者。

;< p>;“这个男孩正在学习背诵《古兰经》，当他无法背诵经文时，老师就打了他一巴掌，”阿尔沙德说，并补充说受害者据说被打了两到三下。

;

;他补充说，警方也知道这起事件，并已与他联系。

;

;香港穆斯林理事会于周三晚首次披露了这起袭击事件，该理事会还敦促教师善待学生带着同情心和父母监督孩子的健康。

;

;根据委员会的说法，周日晚上，男孩说他的“左眼里有东西飞来飞去”，促使他的家人带他去看帕梅拉次日早上，柴湾东区尤德那打素医院。

;

;香港是否该对不断上升的虐儿案件进行反省？

;

;一位眼科专家随后证实，他视网膜脱落并呈 180 度撕裂，并被建议进行两次手术，第一次手术于周三上午进行，另一次计划于六个月后进行。

;

;阿尔沙德谴责了这次袭击，并表示他号召所有的ustadhs（阿拉伯语教师）参加如何在香港教授宗教教育的培训。

;

;“我们必须遵守香港政府的规则，强调有关儿童保护和教育的法律。”虐待儿童，”他说。

;

;“这就是为什么我要召集所有教师开会，对他们进行培训，告诉他们香港的规则和我们的宗教，这是不允许殴打的。 ”

;

;一位未透露姓名的学习中心发言人表示，当《华盛顿邮报》联系他们时，他们需要先与家长交谈。

;

;当被问及男孩是否被老师打了，需要做眼部手术，他说：“不不不，不是那样的，不是那样的事情。”

;

;但他补充说，他知道这个男孩以前有过眼部问题。

;

;香港警方调查涉嫌在幼儿园虐待 3 岁女孩

;

;周三晚上，该委员会分享了据称来自该男孩的即时消息的屏幕截图

;

;其中一条消息称：“我弟弟的视力一直很差，需要请专家检查眼睛。”

;

;根据消息，姐姐说该中心已“多次”被告知她哥哥的眼睛问题，并补充说她相信他以前被老师打过，但没有告诉他的家人。

;

;该委员会表示，该学生接受了六次视力检查。 ” 一个小时的手术，并被他的图像“深深震惊”。

;

;

;该委员会还表示正在与男孩的家人、法律顾问和其他伊斯兰组织成员保持联系，“非常严肃地对待此案，而不是简单地将其视为一次性‘意外’案件，因为事实并非如此”。

;

;“所有伊玛目、乌斯塔德和宗教学校教师都需要承担责任，以确保他们以同情心、智慧并按照安拉和先知的教义教导年轻人，”委员会写道。

;

;还呼吁家长监督孩子的健康，不要让任何身体、情感或精神虐待行为逍遥法外。

;

;在雪兰莪州莎阿南法院，穆罕默德·萨菲克 (Muhamad Safiq)根据新法律，罗斯利被指控多次跟踪 31 岁的摄影师 Acacia Mardiana Daud。他不认罪。

;

;地方法官 Sasha Diana Sabtu 还向 Acacia 颁发了保护令，禁止被告在整个法庭诉讼期间与受害人及其家人联系，规定这是未来案件的先例。

;

;被告因在英国骚扰 Acacia 而被英国当局拘留，并于 4 月份潜逃英国，随后被拒绝保释，据称他在英国仍是一名通缉犯。 2022 年，为了避免他的骚扰，她搬到了伦敦。

;

;“直到今天，我在马来西亚都感觉不安全。他试图亲自找到我。我告诉他我不感兴趣，”她在 X（该平台以前称为 Twitter）上说道。

;

;她 7 月份的推文引起了人们对她处境的关注，在 Twitter 和当地媒体上吸引了超过 1600 万次浏览、政府部长和马来西亚皇家警察，这是对备受推崇的新反跟踪法的首次测试。

;

;在其中，她讲述了早在 2016 年 Safiq 据称是如何跟踪她的使用 30 多个 Instagram 帐户以及 Twitter 和电子邮件，主动向她家送花，发送淫秽性信息，以及亲自出席她参加的活动，导致她受到创伤。

;

;妇女援助组织 (WAO) 在马来西亚将跟踪行为定为犯罪方面发挥了重要作用，该组织表示，他们仍在敦促政府确保警察和前线救援人员意识到跟踪是一种犯罪行为，因此受害者不会被拒绝或被告知他们的案件无法调查。

;

;“将会有很多案件会被举报，特别是在这项指控之后，所以我们希望统计数据能够得到整理”，WAO 的宣传总监阿比纳亚·莫汉 (Abinaya Mohan) 告诉《亚洲周刊》。 “只有掌握相关数据，我们才能真正了解马来西亚的情况有多严重。”

;

;韩国将跟踪行为定为刑事犯罪后的第一年，她表示当地警方已记录了 5,000 起案件，并呼吁提高人们对跟踪行为的认识。

;

;虽然马来西亚社交媒体用户对这一消息感到欢欣鼓舞，但许多人感到震惊的是，Acacia 的案件在其案件真正流行之前才公开并在网上疯传。

;

;“女性应得的更好的。我们不应该乞求公众帮助让我们的跟踪者和袭击者为他们的罪行承担责任，”Twitter 用户 The Shazana 说道，他对 Acacia 的起诉书帖子做出了回应。

;香港应修改为期三个月的警告系统，以保护工人免受热应激，一个环保组织和专家警告说，由于它没有考虑到城市不同地区的气温差异。

;

;香港绿色和平组织周四表示，上个月进行的一项研究显示，该市的炎热指数结果可能会各地的气温差异很大，但天文台仅根据九龙京士柏气象站的读数发出警告。

;

;“日益严重的气候危机正导致气温逐年上升。该组织的活动人士汤姆·吴汉林 (Tom Ng Hon-lam) 表示：“我们要求当局在明年极端高温到来之前为工人提供最好的保护。”

;

;对香港的新高温预警系统感到热衷和烦恼吗？邮报已给出答案

;

;香港劳工处于五月推出三级热应激预警系统，该系统以天文台与中文大学共同开发的香港高温指数为基础，考虑了相对湿度、阳光强度和温度。

;

;一旦该指数达到 30，该市就会发出黄色警报，如果分别达到 32 或 34，该市就会升级为红色或黑色警报。

;

;根据所发出的信号和工作强度，建议工人暂停工作或休息15至45分钟。

;

;自7月31日以来，该部门已发出47次黄色警告，但尚未采取行动。发出红色或黑色信号。

;

;自2014年以来，高温指数仅四次达到需要红色预警的水平。 No past readings have hit the threshold for a black signal.

;

;But critics have complained about the sudden issuing and cancelling of warnings, leaving workers and employers confused over when to rest or return to their duties.

;

;On July 5, an amber warning was issued at 2.20pm and cancelled an hour later. It then came back into effect some 10 minutes later.

;

;The department in May published voluntary guidance on heatstroke prevention as a reminder for employers and staff to take appropriate measures when working in hot weather or environments.

;

;Ren Chao, an associate professor of applied climatology and climate design at the University of Hong Kong, said any guidance should take into consideration “differences in the microclimate within the same city”.

;

;“The release of heatstroke prevention guidelines purely based on the meteorological data from the King's Park Meteorological Station cannot properly represent the heat conditions of different districts in Hong Kong,” she said.

;

;In a three-day survey, Greenpeace last month collected data from seven construction sites and recorded discrepancies of up to 8 degree Celsius (46.4 Fahrenheit) between the temperature readings taken.

;

;How to improve heat stress warnings for workers and avoid flip-flops

;

;Dr Ignatius Yu Tak-sun, chairman of the Hong Kong Workers' Health Centre, said the city's heat index was not “an appropriate method to measure [labourers'] heat stress during work”.

;

;Former Observatory director Shun Chi-ming earlier suggested authorities merge the warning system and the heat index to prevent any inconsistencies between the two.

;

;Greenpeace on Thursday also recommended the government peg the system to other heat-related signals, such as the “very hot weather” warning, as well as offer real-time monitoring at construction sites and issue preliminary warnings to avoid sudden cancellations.

;

;The Post has contacted the Labour Department for comment.

;

;Deputy Commissioner for Labour Vincent Fung Hao-yin last month told a Legislative Council session that the department would look at possible improvements after the summer.

; Thu, 10 Aug 2023 19:20:02 +0800 Malaysia state polls: could TikTok domination give Perikatan Nasional the edge?https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3230623/malaysia-state-polls-could-tiktok-domination-give-perikatan-nasional-edge?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.10 17:30;
;;

;Malaysia's opposition appears to be winning the social media battle ahead of Saturday's crunch state elections with paid-for YouTube and Facebook content and live TikTok videos partly replacing door-to-door canvassing, a contrast to Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's anaemic efforts to reach voters over the internet.

;

;The polls, contested in six of Malaysia's 13 states – including the industrial powerhouses of Selangor and Penang held by Pakatan Harapan (PH) – are widely seen as a barometer of support for Anwar's eight-month-old administration.

;

;Critics say Anwar's administration has lost its fizz, bogged down by a sluggish economy, fissures in his coalition and a resurgent Perikatan Nasional (PN) opposition – including the Islamist PAS party – which has leapt on culture wars and accuses the government of failing the country's Malay majority population.

;

;Malaysia's Selangor polls could drive referendum on Anwar's unity government

;

;PN's dominance on TikTok, a platform used by an estimated half of Malaysians, has even irked communications minister Fahmi Fadzil, who on Sunday accused the opposition of paying to inflate view counts.

;

;On stage in the leafy upmarket neighbourhood of Bukit Antarabangsa, Fahmi, who is campaigning for the government, told candidates not to be disheartened by the opposition's winning social media strategy – particularly TikTok.

;

;“When we look at TikTok, if Papagomo or Sanusi has tens of thousands of views, these views can be acquired by anyone who wants to spend the money,” said Fahmi, mentioning two top opposition figures. “They are lying with their view counts.”

;

;His comments came after a live TikTok session featuring the enigmatic chief minister of the northwestern Kedah state, Muhammad Sanusi Md Nor, and political commentator Wan Muhammad Azri Wan Deris – popularly known as Papagomo – garnered more than 62,000 views on the platform, a number that PH is struggling to match.

;

;The video pulled 16 million likes, owing to the platform's feature of allowing viewers to like a live video several times.

;

;The platform is a connection point in the Malay heartlands to criticism of Anwar's government, as well as culture wars stoking over everything from the position of Islam in daily life to what is shown in Malaysian cinemas.

;

;If the opposition cuts through to those heartlands, experts say Anwar could be in for a bruising at the polls.

;

;Pro-PN vlogger Nurpais Ismail hit back at allegations of juicing up social media reach.

;

;“They [PH] cannot accept the fact that the people nowadays – on TikTok for example – are more interested in listening to PN leadership, especially Sanusi,” Nurpais said in his latest vlog across social media platforms.

;

;Relatively unknown prior to his appointment as Kedah chief minister in 2020, Sanusi's meteoric rise over the last five years has seen him emerging as the de facto “poster boy” of PN, eclipsing more senior leaders such as former prime minister Muhyiddin Yassin and PAS president Abdul Hadi Awang.

;

;Can Malaysia's Umno help PM Anwar win back Malay voters in August state polls?

;

;Anwar's PH – and its previous incarnations – once led the way in social media outreach in the blogging era of the early noughties. But experts say the coalition has dropped the ball with TikTok.

;

;Instead, PH has had a combative relationship with the platform, with Fahmi summoning its Malaysian representatives during the first week on the job, claiming TikTok hosted “so much extremist and racist content”.

;

;This Week in Asia was unable to reach the minister for comment despite several attempts.

;

;TikTok's policy on Government, Politician, and Political Party Account (GPPPA) prohibits political advertising, including the use of promotional tools available on the platform which is imposed at the account level.

;

;“This means that accounts we identify as belonging to politicians and political parties have their access to advertising features turned off,” the platform said in its published policy on the matter.

;

;Similarly, political accounts are restricted from TikTok's monetisation features, preventing them from giving or receiving any money through the platform.

;

;PN has, however, been openly buying ads on other platforms, including Meta's Facebook and Google's YouTube.

;

;On YouTube, the party uses the platform's skippable in-stream ads that play before videos, carrying election messages on the rising cost of living and stagnant wages.

;

;Anwar and PH are more comfortable on Twitter, their platform of choice in two successful elections in 2018 and 2022, and are backed up by government media.

;

;Political analyst James Chin criticised PH's social media strategy as uncoordinated and “all over the place”.

;

;“Even PN's lousiest video to me is better than a PH video,” Chin said. “The question is how come they did not learn the lesson from the November 2022 election, when it was obvious that social media plays an important role among the young Malay voters.”

;

;Social media strategist Zulfadzli Halim played down the impact of PN messaging after losing several prominent opinion leaders.

;

;“They also have no new materials and are left repeating the same talking points,” he said, mostly on the cost-of-living issue.

;China's top graft-buster said it detained more than 140 officials from state-owned enterprises for corruption investigations in the first half of the year, while over 200 turned themselves in.

;

;The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection said the number of SOEs placed under investigation had “increased significantly” compared with the same period last year, but it did not give a figure for 2022.

;

;It made the announcement in a report posted to the CCDI website on Thursday. 1月至6月被拘留的142名国有企业员工中，约有57人是公司党委委员。 Committee members are typically the top decision-makers at companies within China's party-state system.

;

;China is fed up with corrupt grain system, and it will pay you to snitch

;

;The CCDI also said it had achieved “multiple breakthroughs” in state-owned assets supervision and the energy, electricity, car and corporate finance sectors.

;

;Cracking down on corruption in SOEs was listed as a priority for the graft-buster this year at a CCDI meeting in January, when state-run firms were described as the “ballast” of the economy and critical to President Xi Jinping's development agenda.

;

;In March, the CCDI began inspections of 30 of the country's biggest SOEs directly managed by the state, including China National Nuclear Corporation, China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation, China Rongtong Asset Management Group, China National Petroleum Corporation, and China Three Gorges Corporation.

;

;In Thursday's report, the CCDI said its inspectors had focused on areas vulnerable to corruption such as big infrastructure projects, procurement, mergers and acquisitions, and mixed-ownership reforms of SOEs.

;

;The report also said CCDI teams had investigated “many” senior cadres at the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission, China Huaneng Group, China State Shipbuilding Corporation, PetroChina, State Grid Corporation, China FAW Group, Sinochem and China Post.

;

;The graft-buster has released several updates on the SOE crackdown since the end of March. The most recent was on May 12, when it said seven managers from the electricity, oil and gas, coal, chemicals, military and car sectors were being investigated.

;

;The CCDI said in an April report that it would provide the updates to show its resolve to stamp out corruption in SOEs. It took aim at the leadership in some SOEs who tried to “cover up their wrongdoings” and said “irregular approval procedures” were still “very prominent” in the sector.

;

;Here are 3 anti-corruption tools in China's arsenal that may be underutilised

;

;Former bosses of SOEs have also been caught up in the CCDI campaign, including former party secretary and chairman of China Everbright Group Tang Shuangning, former deputy party secretary and deputy general manager of China National Petroleum Corporation Xu Wenrong, and former party secretary and chairman of China Everbright Group Li Xiaopeng.

;

;Alfred Wu, an associate professor at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy at the National University of Singapore, said there were national objectives behind Beijing's drive to clean up SOEs.

;

;“It wants the SOEs to not only deliver financial results, but also to help with social goals like creating employment and developing indigenous technologies,” Wu said.

;

;“All of those goals will be unobtainable if the SOEs continue to remain a hotbed of corruption.”

;

;Huashang Newspaper reported on August 7 that the unnamed girl, who studies at an exclusive international kindergarten costing 50,000 yuan (US$7,000) annually, was allegedly pushed underwater four times by the swim coach late last month.

;

;The school in Zhejiang, eastern China, dismissed the man, but he is not under any investigation for the alleged assault.

;

;Surveillance footage from the school's swimming pool shows the coach, who was not named in the report, tugging on the girl's arm to pull her away from two classmates nearby, then repeatedly pressing her head underwater.

;

;No one reported the incident to authorities or informed the girl's parents. When the girl's mother was giving her a bath at home later that day, she said her daughter stopped her when she tried to wash her hair.

;

;“Mother, I don't want to wash my hair. I'm afraid of choking,” the girl told her mother.

;

;The alarmed mother soon got the full story from her daughter about what had happened earlier.

;

;“The coach pushed me underwater, and when I came back up, he did it again. It happened many times,” the girl said.

;

;The following day the mother and the girl's grandfather went to the kindergarten to check the surveillance video of the pool area.

;

;The 46-second clip reportedly showed that at 2.40pm on July 27, the coach pulled the girl over at least four times even after she tried to move away from him and pushed the child's head in the water.

;

;The angry family then confronted the coach, but he claimed the girl was disruptive and “naughty” in class.

;

;“When the girl's grandfather asked the coach why he treated her so cruelly, he said that he punished her because her splashing water in the pool affected other children,” the mother said.

;

;The coach was dismissed from his position shortly afterwards.

;

;“The coach is our third-party employee. Now we are terminating his duties,” a teacher at the school, surnamed Fang, told Huashang Newspaper.

;

;Fang also said the kindergarten had apologised to the girl's family but had not asked the coach to do the same because they thought it would hurt his pride.

;

;There has been no report of any further investigation by mainland authorities into the matter.

;

;The story outraged many people on Chinese social media.

;

;One person commented: “Is it just a physical punishment? He looked like he was drowning the little girl.”

;

;Another said: “Poor little girl! She will be scared of water for the rest of her life.”

;

;Cases of abuse by teachers are common in China.

;

;Last month, a private school in eastern China was hit with accusations that a teacher abused students and forced them to participate in slapping, spitting and humiliating each other.

;

;In May, a secondary school teacher in southwestern China caused public anger after forcing her class to put their mobile phones in a water basin as a warning not to bring them into class.

;Niger's junta named a new government overnight, forcing its agenda before a summit on Thursday of regional leaders who have demanded that they end their military takeover.

;

;West African heads of state meeting in Nigeria aim to agree on a plan of action for Niger, where coup leaders have refused to stand down despite the bloc's threat that it could use force to restore democracy.

;

;Since the July 26 power grab shocked the region, the defiant junta has rebuffed diplomatic overtures and ignored an August 6 deadline from the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) to reinstate ousted president Mohamed Bazoum.

;

;Mahamane Roufai Laouali, cited as “Secretary General of the Government”, read out 21 names on state television without specifying any further plans.

;

;Three coup leaders were named ministers of defence, interior and sports. Former Finance Minister Ali Mahamane Lamine Zeine, who had been named prime minister on Monday, was appointed finance minister for the new government.

;

;Niger's previous government had 43 ministers. None of them were military officers.

;

;UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres voiced concern about Bazoum and his family after his party reported that they were being detained at the presidential residence without electricity or running water, and had gone days without fresh food.

;

;“The Secretary General … once again calls for his immediate, unconditional release and his reinstatement as Head of State,” a UN spokesperson said on Wednesday.

;

;The meeting in the Nigerian capital, Abuja, could prove a pivotal moment in the stand-off. The bloc's leaders are expected to agree on next steps, which could include military intervention – something an Ecowas official has said would be a last resort.

;

;In nearby Senegal, where the government has said it could send troops if needed, people's views about a military intervention differed.

;

;“As long as we act to restore peace I'm a supporter,” Lansanna Diedhiou said near a weekly market in the capital Dakar. “The objective of the organisation is … to act together for the African family.”

;

;Others, like Cheikh Niang, were concerned about the impact on regional ties and solidarity.

;

;“We're all Africans and Niger is part of the African continent,” he said. “We can't send Africans to wage war against each other.”

;

;Envoys of the Nigerian president and Ecowas chair Bola Tinubu met coup leaders in the capital, Niamey, on Wednesday, offering a glimmer of hope for dialogue after previous missions were spurned.

;

;Any escalation would further destabilise West Africa's Sahel region, one of the world' poorest, where a long-running Islamist insurgency has displaced millions and stoked a hunger crisis.

;

;The coup was triggered by internal politics but it has evolved into an international entanglement, with Ecowas, the United Nations and Western countries putting pressure on the junta to stand down, while military governments in neighbouring Mali and Burkina Faso have vowed to defend it.

;

;The military takeover has raised questions over whether the United States can continue the 1,100-strong military presence in Niger that officials and analysts say has been key to fighting Islamist militants in the Sahel region.

;

;A complicating factor could be any decision by Niger's coup leaders to seek help from Russia's Wagner Group, which the US has designated a transnational criminal organisation. Wagner's chief, Yevgeny Prigozhin, has welcomed the coup in Niger and said his forces were available to restore order.

;

;Niger accused France on Wednesday of violating its airspace, attacking a military camp and freeing “terrorists” to undermine the country. Paris denied the charges.
